column3: A blueprint for creating objects in Java, defining fields and methods.
An instance of a class that contains data and methods to manipulate that data.
A block of code that performs a specific task, defined inside a class.
A container that stores a value of a specific data type.
Specifies the type of value a variable can hold, such as int, double, or String.
The entry point for Java applications: public static void main(String[] args).
The concept of bundling data with the methods that operate on it.
A mechanism where a class can inherit properties and behavior from another class.
The ability of an object to take many forms, typically by overriding methods.
The process of hiding implementation details and showing only the essential features.
A sequence of characters enclosed in double quotes in Java.
A control structure that repeats a block of code multiple times.
A loop that executes a specific number of times with a counter variable.
A loop that executes while a condition is true.
A loop that executes at least once before checking the condition.
A collection of elements of the same type stored in a contiguous memory location.
The position of an element in an array, starting from 0.
Simplified syntax for iterating over arrays and collections.
A mutable sequence of characters used to efficiently modify strings.
Used to exit a loop before it naturally terminates.
A special method used to initialize objects when they are created.
Defining multiple methods with the same name but different parameters.
Redefining a superclass method in a subclass to provide specific behavior.
The process of handling runtime errors using try, catch, and finally blocks.
A namespace that organizes related classes and interfaces.
Used to include other packages or classes into a Java file.
Defines the visibility of classes, methods, and variables (e.g., public, private, protected).
Indicates that a member belongs to the class rather than an instance.
A reference type containing abstract methods that classes can implement.
Used to declare constants or prevent method overriding or inheritance.
